Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Magellanic Clouds as a Laboratory for Star Formation at Low Metallicity
Award.AbstractNarration:
These astronomers seek to understand what causes clouds of gas in space to collapse to form stars. The immediate cause is the force of gravity, but why gravity acts quickly on some clouds and slowly in others remains a puzzle. The investigators have a plan to solve this puzzle by using detailed observations of gas clouds located in two nearby satellite galaxies, the Magellanic Clouds. The observations, taken with NSF’s Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array’s (ALMA) observatory, will have the quality and detail needed to measure the properties of the gas. The investigators will compare measurements of the stellar environment with the locations and ages of young stars. The investigators are from three different universities, and each will contribute to training of next generation scientists. The students will get hands-on experience in the techniques of scientific data analysis and instrumentation. The team will develop of new virtual reality tools for improving the public understanding of science.

With the ALMA’s unprecedented sensitivity and access to the southern sky, astronomers are beginning to resolve the clumpy, filamentary structure of molecular clouds in the Magellanic Clouds. Analysis has shown that the velocity dispersion of the molecular gas at a given scale increases with the overall star formation activity of the cloud, suggesting that energetic feedback from young stars plays a significant role in maintaining turbulent motions within the cloud. However, other lines of evidence, including our finding that clumps and filaments are typically marginally unstable to collapse, support the view that increased velocity dispersion and star formation can both be driven by gravitational instability. The investigators plan observations to reveal the conditions for star formation. They will use a broad, survey-based, approach which can identify regions deficient in one of the key ingredients (e.g., young stars or dense gas) and thus more accurately distinguish cause and effect. Combining ALMA imaging of the molecular gas on sub-parsec scales with infrared surveys of the young stellar populations in these galaxies will provide new insights into the roles of triggering, feedback, and cloud conditions in the star formation process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our understanding of the initial conditions for star formation is strongly biased by studies of molecular clouds in the solar neighborhood. In order to gain a broader perspective on the factors that impact the ability of gas to form stars, we have been surveying the molecular cloud and young star populations in the nearest star-forming galaxies, the Magellanic Clouds, which exhibit lower chemical abundances and less organized galactic structure than the Milky Way.  This research uses the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA), a uniquely powerful facility located in the southern hemisphere and hence having a fantastic view of the Magellanic Clouds.  

ALMA mapped the molecular gas in 30 Doradus (a.k.a. Tarantula Nebula), the most active star formation in the Large Magellanic Cloud, and NGC 346, the most active star formation region in the Small Magellanic Cloud.  A CO image of the 30 Doradus cloud was featured in press releases coordinated by NRAO and ESO for the June 2022 AAS meeting (Figure 1). The paper presenting the analysis of the cloud's structure, Wong et al. (2022), was also published at the time of the AAS meeting. Many previous studies have found CO cloud structures to be close to virial equilibrium (a fancy way of saying that gravity and expansive motions are in balance). However, from previous work we already suspected that the 30 Doradus cloud might be an exception to this rule, which would not come as a surprise because it lies adjacent to the greatest known concentration of young massive stars in our Local Group of galaxies. The new observations reveal a more complex picture. The denser filaments in the cloud are still in virial equilibrium, but there are many smaller and lower density "cloudlets" that are not virialized, and which we interpret as regions being disrupted by feedback.  We're not sure why other CO clouds don't tend to show these un-virialized cloudlets, but it could be that they are simply more difficult to detect in less active clouds.  Subsequent work by Green et al. (2024), comparing a set of clouds with varying levels of star formation activity, reveals the clear signature of feedback from massive star formation as manifested in excess line width measured in the CO clouds.  A paper by Indebetouw et al. (2024) uses the special properties of the formaldehyde molecule to measure the cloud temperatures, finding evidence that most clouds are externally heated by stellar radiation.

To identify the young stars forming in the molecular gas we used infrared space telescope data, such as Spitzer, Herschel and the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST).  In the study by Nayak et al. (2023) we increased the number of known young stellar objects in the 30 Doradus region by an order of magnitude with the Spitzer and Herschel catalogs (see Figure 2).  Comparing the newly formed stars with their molecular gas, we determined a 40% higher surface mass density requirement for star formation in the 30 Doradus region than in our Milky Way.  We also measured higher turbulence in the molecular clouds close to the central cluster of 30 Doradus, demonstrating the importance of stellar feedback on star formation.  Indeed, the higher turbulence may cause the higher threshold. Of the 299 YSO candidates in this work, 62% are not associated with CO molecular gas. This large fraction can be explained by the fact that 75%-97% of the molecular gas (i.e. H2 gas) is not traced by CO. The rate of star formation in 30 Doradus, using this new catalog of YSOs, has increased in the past few million years.

Our study of NGC 346 by Lenkic et al. (in preparation) reveals the properties of the molecular clouds with some similarities to what we find in 30 Doradus.  We applied similar structure-finding algorithms to facilitate comparison with our earlier work (Figure 3).  Gas temperatures are derived with warmer spots being closer to known young stellar objects. Gas is more turbulent in this region compared to the Milky Way and hence similar to the gas turbulence in 30 Doradus.  

We have also engaged young people in educational experiences related to the goals of the project.  At Illinois, we developed a spectroscopy activity for the Girls' Astronomy Summer Camp to help demonstrate the different types of spectra produced from different gases.  At Virginia, we developed a virtual reality (VR) learning module about star formation, using the real molecular cloud data from 30 Dor observed with ALMA for this project, as well as a simulation of a protoplanetary disk and many other visual resources.
